timeline.subject: Jean Colas Claude Martin and Jennon Martin
timeline.details: Taken by prévôt at St Dié at request of Rémy, supported by Change de Nancy, following accusations by Jean Demenge Olry of Lubine

timeline.subject: Jean and Jennon
timeline.details: Rémy asks that Jean be given question ordinaire et extraordinaire, but torture of Jennon only to be mediocre

timeline.subject: Jean and Jennon
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture

timeline.subject: Jean Colas Claude Martin
timeline.details: Given thumbscrews, racked, and subjected to tortillons; tortured a second time more lightly same day, then briefly the next; continued to deny

timeline.subject: Jennon Martin
timeline.details: Lightly racked only; denied all charges

timeline.subject: Jean and Jennon
timeline.details: Rémy agrees they cannot be convicted, but asks Jean be banished due to weight of evidence

timeline.subject: Jean and Jennon
timeline.details: Change de Nancy decides they should be renvoyés (released) with admonition to conduct themselves in future so there are no complaints

torture.restrictions: Jean: ordinaire et extraordinaire; Jennon: mediocre only (lightly racked only in practice)

prior_accusations.context: 8 years earlier told Jennon she was not a virgin, but had relations with 'noir homme disant le diable'

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Colas Claude Martin (to witness 1)
notable_quotes.french: Ja Dieu ne les laisse tant vivre que de faire telles choses
notable_quotes.english: May God not let them live long enough to do such things
notable_quotes.context: Denying he caused harm to animals

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Colas Claude Martin
notable_quotes.french: et que Dieu l'en garde que s'il vient ung maladie a ung on n'en doibt charger son voisin que de luy il en a bien heu qu'il n'en charge personne
notable_quotes.english: and may God keep him from it, that if an illness comes to someone one must not blame one's neighbor; he himself has had enough that he does not blame anyone

notable_quotes.speaker: Colas Guillemotte (witness 2)
notable_quotes.french: et ne se peut contenir d'en arguer ledit Jean Colas Claude Martin, encor que c'estoit couvertement, toutesfois de ces propos pouvoit il bien entendre que c'estoit de luy qu'on parloit
notable_quotes.english: and could not contain himself from accusing said Jean Colas Claude Martin, although it was covertly, nevertheless from these words he could well understand that it was him being spoken of
notable_quotes.context: Witness describing how he blamed Jean for loss of ox

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Chapel (witness 7's father) to Jean's future wife
notable_quotes.french: le peu de respect qu'elle portoit a son parentaige qui avoit esté de tout temps en estime fame et renommée d'honnesteté et vertu sans qu'il y ait eheu soupcon de quelque malefice
notable_quotes.english: the little respect she showed to her lineage which had been at all times in esteem, fame and renowned for honesty and virtue without there having been suspicion of any malefice
notable_quotes.context: Reproaching woman for marrying into witch family

notable_quotes.speaker: Wife of Jean Claude Olry of Colroy
notable_quotes.french: le diable soit de genox de la haute rue
notable_quotes.english: the devil be of the knees of the high street
notable_quotes.context: Blaming Jean and Jennon (who lived on high street) for husband's illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonnée femme Jean Demenge Olry (witness 17) to Jennon
notable_quotes.french: que des gens de bien y avoient bien estez sans appeller, mais que les meschant n'y avoient volu aller, que savoient faict des genox et des genoxe qui l'avoient faict mourir
notable_quotes.english: that good people had been there without being called, but that the wicked had not wanted to go there, who knew of the knees and the kneeling ones who had caused it to die
notable_quotes.context: Accusing Jennon of causing death of bull

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Martin
notable_quotes.french: sy elle pouvoit faire paroistre qu'elle l'eust faict mourir qu'on la chastie bien
notable_quotes.english: if she could show that she had caused it to die, let her be punished well
notable_quotes.context: Response to accusation about bull's death

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Demenge Olry to Jean (according to maire)
notable_quotes.french: que s'ils ne se retiroient il leur monstreroit ung tour d'homme
notable_quotes.english: that if they did not withdraw he would show them a man's trick
notable_quotes.context: Olry's threat when accused and sister sought reparation

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Colas Claude Martin at end of torture
notable_quotes.french: que l'on luy at rapporté qu'on a menassé les tesmoings s'ilz ne deposent tel l'ung tel l'autre
notable_quotes.english: that he has been told that the witnesses were threatened if they did not testify such and such
notable_quotes.context: Final statement under torture claiming witnesses were coerced

notable_quotes.speaker: une sarazine to Jennon (8 years before)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle luy feroit une belle dance
notable_quotes.english: that she would make her a fine dance
notable_quotes.context: Threat after Jennon refused to give her lard

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over animals damaging gardens and fields; tax dispute; damage to fences; theft of firewood. Jean's marriage to widow of good lineage was controversial due to his suspect reputation. Jean worked as carpenter and smith, traveled for work.

historical_context.military_details: Previous Lent, just after soldiers had left the village, children took wood from garden fence. Reference to payment for artillery horses at Easter.
weather_events: rainstorm during which Jean Olriot and Jean sheltered under tree

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jean Olriot called Jennon witch publicly without any action following; Colas Guillemotte reproached Jean publicly without action; when accused and sister sought reparation from Jean Demenge Olry, he threatened them

legal_context.redress_outcome: According to maire, when accused and sister sought reparation, Jean Demenge Olry said 'if they did not withdraw he would show them a man's trick'

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: accused Colas Guillemotte of having committed perjury
said George Jacquemin once struck him after reproaching him for wanting to have a girl - did not know if he bore ill-will
said Benitte femme Demenge Doienney was relative on mother's side of his 'partie contraire' Jean Demenge Olry, might have advantaged him in testimony
according to maire, when accused and sister sought reparation Olry said if they did not withdraw he would show them a man's trick
said he had been away working at Mesangoutte or Repas at time in question
said Claudon Jean Boullon was relative of Olry and might have deposed against him for that reason
said Jean Olriot was Olry's father-in-law
said Jean Demenge de la Borse was a good man, and that a year earlier he might have married his sister 'n'eust esté une parolle'

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a particularly rich and detailed trial record with 30 witnesses providing extensive testimony. Jean and Jennon were both accused, tortured, but ultimately released. The case shows strong community divisions with the main accuser Jean Demenge Olry having familial connections to multiple witnesses. Jean's marriage to a widow of good lineage was controversial. The accused challenged witness credibility effectively, noting family relationships. The trial demonstrates the counter-magic practice of taking 'joutte' from the suspected witch's garden to cure ailments. Jean had an established carpentry career and traveled for work. Both accused maintained innocence under torture. The prosecutor Rémy recommended banishment for Jean but the Change de Nancy ordered release with admonition. Trial lasted 38 days from arrest to release.
